body:
@mostaphaRoudsari ,

I have implemented all that you have requested with a few minor edits:
https://github.com/HydraShare/hydra/commit/326a01c68ba02f9d4f01a39a8573eeed84abcc72

Instead of writing "Changelog" I have just written the version of the component and then any change log text below it.  This will make it not look weird if someone is committing a file for the first time or does not want to include a changelog.  I also put in some functions to parse and read any old README (if it exists) such that the change log will be a running list of all versions of the file that a user has uploaded.

Also, there is no need to require the user to input their github username to the component since I can find out what their username is through the config file in the .git folder of their fork on their computer.  Generally, I want to try to make as few required inputs as possible since I could tell that this was a big barrier to entry for new people just trying out the component.

Along the line of the user's account name, I also put in a link to the user's account in the README so that people can go from the hydra page to the user's page if they want to access all of the example files that someone has uploaded (if you have any easy way of generating this page, I think that a lot of people will want quick access to it).

Let me know if I am forgetting anything and, if not, close out the issue!

-Chris

I had to fix a few bugs:
https://github.com/HydraShare/hydra/commit/670fae0b5fefbc7b62e088fca83201393a5f1d60

Here's a page showing the new format:
http://hydrashare.github.io/hydra/viewer?owner=chriswmackey&description=Outdoor_Comfort_Shade_Benefit
This already exists.   Nevermind.

One final commit that gets the thumbnail working correctly:
http://hydrashare.github.io/hydra/viewer?owner=chriswmackey&description=Psychrometric_Chart

@ayezioro ,

Your Armature for Energy-Positive Building Experiment is displaying fine in my firefox:
![gh ok](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5567574/10181006/c6dd0b40-66e0-11e5-88a2-fc8b07ba095f.JPG)

I imagine that your issue is related to the fact that all of those example files have the maximum size possible for the high-res image of the GH canvas.  I might have to drop this size down if we are not able to fix it on your system.

What type of speed do you have for your internet?
http://ma.speedtest.rcn.net/

-Chris

Hi Chris,
I'm at home right now. The test speed  for download is 10.5 Mbps, which is slow from what i expect (30). But i tried this also at my university which gas a pretty much fast connection.
I was thinking that a restart will do, but right now this happened again (black window in firefox).
MS Edge doesn't show the image but a computer screen with a X on it.
The example remaining is the one of your screenshot.
... don't know what to say ...
Thanks,
-A.
P.S. Now in the university. Speed download: 63 Mbps (also low than what i expected but good).

@ayezioro ,
I will admit that I have also had some issues sometimes when I try to load a GH script with a large detailed image.  Refreshing my browser a few times usually gets it to work.  My guess is that this is what is happening in your firefox and I may have to reduce the max image size.
Can you confirm whether you are able to see small images of the canvas as well? Such as this one?
http://hydrashare.github.io/hydra/viewer?owner=chriswmackey&description=Color_Library

If so, Let's try to find the maximum image size before your browser fails and I will set the max image size to that.
My guess with MS edge is that Microsoft is trying to be the usual bully it has historically been in the web development space and they don't support open libraries that the rest of us want to use since they want us to use their proprietary terrible stuff.  I am inclined to forget about them.

-Chris

Hi CHris,
I can see well the link you sent.
I kind of like the MS Edge, though is not my default browser (firefox is).
Chrome is also not happy with some of the links.
See the image:
On the left is what i get in Edge, on the right with Chrome. Firefox is just a black window that i can't even refresh. Everything is disabled.
![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7526023/10201149/33fe15de-67b3-11e5-8d71-bc3630386626.JPG)

Thanks,
-A.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13341935/10205376/dc908148-678e-11e5-9c69-1d36d17b55b3.png)
if anyone takes this on and needs assistance feel free to email or ping me
I think the example is removed. I close the issue for now until we find a new example that has this issue
Also, I have to stop the changelog from being a running list
Hi @elcinertugrul, Just modify or remove them on your fork and it will be updated here. Hydra will always upload the latest version of your file.

@mostaphaRoudsari ,

This issue has now been addressed:
https://github.com/HydraShare/hydra/commit/68e2cacf9449c905d51acd931b1fb0d3c4ec8e39

You can see the new readme in action here:
http://hydrashare.github.io/hydra/viewer?owner=chriswmackey&fork=hydra_2&id=Outdoor_Comfort_Shade_Benefit

Everything should now be solid with the ReadMe and so I am closing out the issue.  If I made a mistake, feel free to re-open.

-Chris
This looks good to me!  I think standardizing the platform is a good idea especially when the Dynamo Component is finished to help keep everything uniform.

@mostaphaRoudsari ,

Excellent!  Your example looks really exciting.  I understand the general idea of allowing people to put up multiple images and trying to make the infrastructure not platform-specific.  However, I was just confused about what is happening on the back end as I see the images in your example are still named 'Rhino' and 'gh' on your fork:
https://github.com/mostaphaRoudsari/hydra_1/tree/master/shadow_range_study
To be more specific, is there some sort of naming scheme that we should follow if we want a certain image to show up first, second, third, etc. in the slide show?

-Chris

@chriswmackey. Thanks. It's not about the file names but the file structure. I left the naming as what it used to be, but what is different between the previous structure and the current one is that all the images are under input.images - They can be named whatever that you want as far as they are available in the folder. In the other word there is no Rhino vs GH images. There are just couple of images.

Good point! There is no naming schema and first image will show up first. I think that's a fair point and we can change the schema to follow an order for images. Something like:

``` javascript
"images" : {     /* 
                        image full name : optional description
                        First image will be loaded by default. All the images should be
                        located in the root folder
                        */
                       "0" : { "image1.jpg" : "Grasshopper definition"},
                        "1": {"image2.gif": "Animated Rhino Scene"},
                        "2": {"image3.png": "Dynamo definition"},
                         "3": {"Image4.tiff": ""}, ...
                   },
```

or it can be simply a list of objects which will be in order. I can implement this change later tonight. It needs changes also in the front end.

@mostaphaRoudsari this looks good - makes it more extendable.  You may want to update the parser script on the viewer code to match the naming convention.  
Question on the image files - are we agnostic to image file types? do the order matter?

@mostaphaRoudsari ,

Thanks for the explanation and it is much clearer now. To drive home my only major suggestions if we want people to use this feature: we should make it clear to them that the images should be in the folder BEFORE running the Hydra component and that the order of images that they want should follow a naming convention.

Also, how do you feel about having the GH script as the first image by default (unless people edit the json file)?  This sounds like a good means of shaping a general structure to the Hydra database while still allowing people to freedom to over-ride it (if they know what they are doing and edit the json).

-Chris

Thanks @ayezioro! As far as I can see the download button is broken. The grasshopper component should still work fine. Remove Galzing is using the old version. Let me check and I will get back to you soon.
Guess who's mistake was that. ;) I just get it fixed. It should work fine now. Thanks for reporting.

I'm guessing ... i'm guessing.
Thanks,
-A.

Added the page to Wiki: https://github.com/HydraShare/hydra/wiki/Hydra-Schema-and-Folder-Structure

I'm closing this for now. It's good if someone can add more text to the page on Wiki to make it more user/developer friendly.

Hi @mdahlhausen. It's not clear to me how to add it to the page but that would be a huge move forward. How does it work? Are they going to take care of keeping the comments? Will it be different for each page address? I'm asking since Hydra is a single page application. Can we have different discussion/commenting for the same page with different hashes?
I'm going to modify the code to use pushState or location.hash for different users. That might also help for this purpose.
This is done and runs every 1 minute. I keep it open until I integrate it into the process.
